metadata.titleEn: MODIS daily cloud-free snow cover area product for Sanjiangyuan from 2000 to 2019
metadata.description:
The dataset was produced based on MODIS data. Parameters and algorithm were revised to be suitable for the land cover type in the Three-River-Source Regions. By using the Markov de-cloud algorithm, SSM/I snow water equivalent data was fused to the result. Finally, high accuracy daily de-cloud snow cover data was produced. The data value is 0(no snow) or 1(snow). The spatial resolution is 500m, the time period is from 2000-2-24 to 2019-12-31.
Data format is geotiff, Arcmap or python+GDAL were recommended to open and process the data.

background: Mid-latitude Alpine snow cover is characterized by rapid seasonal changes and large spatial variations, which play important roles in energy changes, climate, water resources and ecological processes (Dozier and Painter2004). Known as Asia’s water tower, the glaciers and snowpack over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (QTP) provide the headwater for several major rivers in Asia (Xu, Ramanathan, and Washington2016). The water supplied by this region affects approximately 50–60% of the world’s population in China and parts of Asia (Barnett, Adam, and Lettenmaier 2005). Snow cover maps provide information about the spatial extent of the snow cover and are very useful for snow-related research. The snow cover on the plateau has important influences on the atmospheric circulation in the northern hemisphere but also directly affect the climatic and eco-environmental evolution of China (Qin, Liu, and Li2006). Due to the remoteness, topographic complexity and the relative sparsity of meteorological observation over the QTP, remote sensing is the most practical tool for monitoring a snow-covered area over the QTP. Although the snow algorithm developed by the MODIS data group can separate snow from the most obscuring clouds, daily MODIS data still have a relatively high cloud-covered fraction (as high as 47.3% over the QTP according to Tang et al. (2013). The first cloud-free snow cover products were derived from the Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System of the NOAA/NESDIS (Brown et al.2014). The other three snow cover products (MOD-SSM/I, MOD-B, TAI) are essentially produced by MODIS snow cover data.
research objective: The aim of this study is to provide a quantitative assessment of the performance of the currently available four daily cloud-free snow cover products and which product is more efficient for use in hydrologic and climatological applications over the QTP. Based on the assessment, an I-TAI (Improvement of Terra–Aqua–IMS) snow product was proposed, which can improve the accuracy to some extent.
challenges: However, the algorithms of the MODIS series products show instability when identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover over the QTP. The snow misclassification is an important limitation of MODIS snow cover products and requires additional improvements. Although the snow algorithm developed by the MODIS data group can separate snow from the most obscuring clouds, daily MODIS data still have a relatively high cloud-covered fraction (as high as 47.3% over the QTP according to Tang et al. (2013). Cloud cover can significantly limit the application of MODIS snow products (López-Burgos, Gupta, and Clark2013; Parajka and Blöschl 2006; Wang et al.2009).
methods: The third step was to identify perennial snow/ice and land cover based on elevation. When the cloud pixels were at elevations higher than 5800 m, they could also be assigned to a snow-covered pixel. The fourth step was based on the spatial combination of adjacent pixels. Four direct‘side-bordering’ adjacent pixels of the cloud pixel were examined. If at least three of four pixels are defined as snow, then the cloud pixel was also assigned to snow. The last steps adopt the model of the snowline. The aim of this step was to identify the minimum elevation where snow exists and the snow-covered elevation where all pixels above this level were covered by snow. Next, these elevation lines are set as threshold elevations to remove the cloud pixels. The first step consists of the Terra/Aqua combination described above, and the second step is the combination of MODIS images and IMS data.
dataset: In situ measurements of snow depth were provided by the meteorological stations’ network maintained by the China Meteorological Administration (CMA). In this study, snow depths from 91 meteorological stations in the study area were used that were obtained between 2004 and 2014 (downloaded from the CMA Sharing Service System athttp:// cdc.cma.gov.cn). The elevations of the meteorological stations ranged from 1400 to 4900 m, and the average elevation was approximately 3500 m. The first snow cover products are the IMS products of the NOAA/NESDIS (Ramsay1998). The MODIS snow products utilized the Terra/Aqua combination and temporal combination algorithm (Parajka and Blöschl2008).
findings: Comparisons of the IMS, MOD-SSM/I, MOD-B and TAI cloud-free snow products against meteorological stations observations over 10 snow seasons (2004–2013) over the QTP indicated overall accuracies of 76.0%, 89.3%, 92.0% and 92.0%, respectively. The Khat values of the IMS, MOD-SSM/I, MOD-B and TAI products were 0.084, 0.463, 0.428 and 0.526, respectively. The TAI products appear to have the best cloud-removal ability among the four snow products over the QTP.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting remote sensing data for snow cover analysis over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the high cloud-covered fraction in daily MODIS data, which can be as high as 47.3%, significantly limiting the application of snow products and causing misclassification of snow cover, especially in areas with wet snow or forest cover.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'cloud-free snow cover products' in the context of remote sensing over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: Cloud-free snow cover products refer to snow cover maps that have been processed to remove cloud cover, allowing for accurate representation of snow extent. These products are created by using algorithms and combining data from multiple sources, such as MODIS and the Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System (IMS), to account for and eliminate pixels obscured by clouds.

Definition.Question: How is the 'Improvement of Terra–Aqua–IMS (I-TAI) snow product' defined in terms of its application for hydrologic and climatological studies over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The Improvement of Terra–Aqua–IMS (I-TAI) snow product is defined as a refined snow cover product that enhances the accuracy of snow cover detection by integrating data from Terra/Aqua satellites and IMS data. This improved product is designed to better serve hydrologic and climatological applications over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau by addressing limitations such as cloud cover and misclassification of snow in the existing products.

Definition.Question: What defines the 'perennial snow/ice and land cover' identification method used in snow cover mapping?
Definition.Answer: The identification of perennial snow/ice and land cover is defined by using elevation criteria and spatial combination methods. In this approach, cloud pixels at elevations higher than 5800 meters are classified as snow-covered. The method also examines adjacent pixels, assigning cloud pixels to snow if surrounded by snow-covered pixels, and employs the snowline model to determine minimum snow-covered elevations, thus removing cloud pixels.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in cloud-removal capabilities between the MODIS snow products and the TAI cloud-free snow products?
Comparison.Answer: Both MODIS and TAI snow products aim to provide cloud-free snow cover information. MODIS snow products utilize a temporal combination algorithm to reduce cloud cover; however, they still have a relatively high cloud-covered fraction. The TAI products show better cloud-removal capabilities and appear to have the best performance among the compared products, achieving higher overall accuracy and Khat values.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the spatial and temporal resolution of snow cover datasets influence hydrologic and climatological research applications?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial and temporal resolution of snow cover datasets can significantly influence research applications by determining the level of detail and accuracy in tracking snow cover changes over time. High-resolution datasets allow for better monitoring of rapid seasonal changes and spatial variations, which are crucial for understanding energy balance, climate impacts, and water resource management in mountainous regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in accurately identifying snow cover using remote sensing data on the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in accurately identifying snow cover using remote sensing data on the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau are primarily due to the instability of algorithms when identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover. Additionally, the high cloud-covered fraction in daily MODIS data, which can be as high as 47.3%, significantly limits the application of MODIS snow products.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is remote sensing considered the most practical tool for monitoring snow-covered areas over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Remote sensing is considered the most practical tool for monitoring snow-covered areas over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau due to the region's remoteness, topographic complexity, and the relative sparsity of meteorological observations. These factors make ground-based observation methods less feasible, necessitating the use of remote sensing technologies for effective monitoring.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the development of cloud-free snow cover products for the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The development of cloud-free snow cover products for the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau is driven by the need to overcome the limitations imposed by cloud cover in daily MODIS data. Techniques such as the Interactive Multisensor Snow and Ice Mapping System and the use of algorithms for the Terra/Aqua combination and temporal combination are employed to improve the accuracy and usability of snow cover data in this region.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences for snow monitoring accuracy when using improved snow extraction algorithms in remote sensing data collection?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of improved snow extraction algorithms in remote sensing data collection can lead to increased accuracy in identifying the extent of snow cover, particularly in areas with complex terrain and cloud cover. This improvement enhances the reliability of snow cover maps, which are crucial for understanding energy changes, climate impacts, water resources, and ecological processes. Additionally, it can mitigate the limitations of traditional methods, which often face challenges like cloud obstruction.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the integration of in situ measurements and remote sensing data influence the quality and reliability of snow cover datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating in situ measurements with remote sensing data can improve the quality and reliability of snow cover datasets by providing ground truth for validation and calibration of remote sensing observations. This combination can help address issues such as the misclassification of snow under forest cover and enhance the accuracy of snow depth and coverage estimates, particularly in regions with significant elevation variations.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to integrate in situ measurements with remote sensing data in the context of snow cover analysis?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating in situ measurements with remote sensing data is important to validate and improve the accuracy of snow cover products, as remote sensing alone can be limited by cloud cover and misclassification issues, particularly in remote and topographically complex regions like the QTP.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are taken to ensure that snow cover data from remote sensing are cloud-free and accurately reflect the snow extent over complex terrains like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps include using the Terra/Aqua combination to help reduce cloud cover, then combining MODIS images with IMS data. Elevations are used to identify perennial snow/ice and land cover. Cloud pixels over 5800 m are assigned as snow, and spatially adjacent pixels are analyzed to further classify clouds as snow. A model of the snowline is applied to determine minimum snow-covered elevations and remove cloud pixels.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can challenges in identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover be addressed when processing MODIS snow cover data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges in identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover can be addressed by improving the algorithms used in processing MODIS data. The current algorithms show instability in these areas, so additional algorithm enhancements or supplementary data sources may be needed to reduce misclassification.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to combine in situ snow depth measurements with remote sensing data to create comprehensive snow cover datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In situ measurements of snow depth are obtained from meteorological stations, which are then combined with remote sensing data like MODIS snow products. The combination involves using temporal and spatial data integration methods, such as the Terra/Aqua combination and temporal combination algorithm, to enhance the accuracy and reliability of the resulting snow cover datasets.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the generation of cloud-free snow cover products from remote sensing data over complex terrains like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies involve a series of steps including the use of Terra/Aqua combination, spatial combination of adjacent pixels, and snowline models to remove cloud pixels, enhancing the generation of cloud-free snow cover products.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of elevation data enhance the accuracy of snow and land cover identification in snow cover mapping?
Enablement.Answer: By identifying perennial snow/ice and land cover based on elevation, cloud pixels at elevations higher than 5800 m can be assigned as snow-covered, improving accuracy in snow and land cover identification.

Enablement.Question: What challenges in remote sensing data processing require algorithmic improvements for more accurate snow cover identification under forest cover?
Enablement.Answer: The algorithms for MODIS series products show instability when identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover, which necessitates improvements due to misclassification issues.

Expectation.Question: Why might algorithms for identifying snow cover using remote sensing data struggle with differentiating wet snow and snow under forest cover in alpine regions?
Expectation.Answer: The algorithms of the MODIS series products show instability when identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (QTP). This misclassification is an important limitation of MODIS snow cover products and requires additional improvements.

Expectation.Question: Why is there a high cloud-covered fraction in daily MODIS data, and what are the implications for snow cover mapping?
Expectation.Answer: Although the snow algorithm developed by the MODIS data group can separate snow from the most obscuring clouds, daily MODIS data still have a relatively high cloud-covered fraction (as high as 47.3% over the QTP). This cloud cover can significantly limit the application of MODIS snow products.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in using elevation-based methods for snow and cloud pixel classification in remote sensing data?
Expectation.Answer: In elevation-based classification, when cloud pixels are at elevations higher than 5800 m, they could also be assigned to a snow-covered pixel. There is a reliance on spatial combination and elevation lines to determine snow coverage, which can introduce complexities in accurately distinguishing between snow and cloud pixels.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think the use of elevation-based methods is in improving the accuracy of snow cover identification in remote sensing over complex terrains?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of elevation-based methods is quite effective as it helps to distinguish snow cover from clouds, particularly in high-altitude regions where cloud cover is prevalent. Assigning cloud pixels to snow-covered pixels based on elevation and the spatial combination of adjacent pixels enhances the accuracy of snow detection.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how might data from meteorological stations complement remote sensing snow cover products to enhance their accuracy and applicability?
Judgmental.Answer: Data from meteorological stations, such as in situ snow depth measurements, offer ground-truth validation that can enhance the accuracy of remote sensing products. They can be used to assess and adjust the performance of satellite-derived snow cover products, leading to more robust and applicable datasets for climatological and hydrological research.

Assertion.Question: I’m not clear on the challenges faced in accurately identifying snow under forest cover and wet snow in remote sensing data.
Assertion.Answer: The content of relevant papers indicates that algorithms of the MODIS series face instability issues when identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover, which results in snow misclassification. This is a noted limitation of MODIS snow cover products.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how cloud cover affects the application of snow cover data in hydrological and climatological studies.
Assertion.Answer: Cloud cover significantly limits the application of MODIS snow products because it obscures the view, which is crucial for identifying snow cover. The papers mention that daily MODIS data have a relatively high cloud-covered fraction, as high as 47.3% over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau, impacting the accuracy and usability of the data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced when using remote sensing to monitor snow-covered areas over complex topographies and suggest potential improvements.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the instability of MODIS algorithms in identifying wet snow and snow under forest cover, as well as the high cloud-covered fraction in daily MODIS data, which can be as high as 47.3% over the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau (QTP). Improvements could focus on enhancing the snow misclassification algorithms and further reducing cloud cover limitations through advanced cloud-removal techniques such as those used in TAI products.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore various data collection methods for obtaining accurate snow cover information in regions with sparse meteorological observation networks.
Request/Directive.Answer: In regions like the Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau with sparse meteorological observations, remote sensing is the most practical tool. Methods include using MODIS data to separate snow from clouds and employing cloud-removal algorithms such as I-TAI, which integrate data from Terra/Aqua MODIS images and IMS data. Additionally, in situ snow depth measurements from meteorological stations can be used to validate remote sensing data.
